lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: Gregory, o' my word, we'll not carry coals.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: No, for then we should be colliers.
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: I mean, an we be in choler, we'll draw.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: Ay, while you live, draw your neck out o' the collar.
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: I strike quickly, being moved.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: A dog of the house of Montague moves me.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand:
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: therefore, if thou art moved, thou runn'st away.
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: A dog of that house shall move me to stand: I will
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: take the wall of any man or maid of Montague's.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: That shows thee a weak slave; for the weakest goes
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: to the wall.
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: True; and therefore women, being the weaker vessels,
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: are ever thrust to the wall: therefore I will push
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: Montague's men from the wall, and thrust his maids
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: to the wall.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: 'Tis all one, I will show myself a tyrant: when I
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: have fought with the men, I will be cruel with the
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: maids, and cut off their heads.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: The heads of the maids?
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads;
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: take it in what sense thou wilt.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: They must take it in sense that feel it.
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: Me they shall feel while I am able to stand: and
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: 'tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: 'Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst, thou
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: hadst been poor John. Draw thy tool! here comes
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: two of the house of the Montagues.
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: My naked weapon is out: quarrel, I will back thee.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: How! turn thy back and run?
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: Fear me not.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: No, marry; I fear thee!
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: Let us take the law of our sides; let them begin.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: they list.
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: Nay, as they dare. I will bite my thumb at them;
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: ABRAHAM
lines.speaker: ABRAHAM

lines.value: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
lines.speaker: ABRAHAM

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: I do bite my thumb, sir.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: ABRAHAM
lines.speaker: ABRAHAM

lines.value: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
lines.speaker: ABRAHAM

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: [Aside to GREGORY]  Is the law of our side, if I say
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: ay?
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: No.
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir, but I
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: bite my thumb, sir.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: Do you quarrel, sir?
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: ABRAHAM
lines.speaker: ABRAHAM

lines.value: Quarrel sir! no, sir.
lines.speaker: ABRAHAM

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: If you do, sir, I am for you: I serve as good a man as you.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: ABRAHAM
lines.speaker: ABRAHAM

lines.value: No better.
lines.speaker: ABRAHAM

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: Well, sir.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: GREGORY
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: Say 'better:' here comes one of my master's kinsmen.
lines.speaker: GREGORY

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: Yes, better, sir.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: ABRAHAM
lines.speaker: ABRAHAM

lines.value: You lie.
lines.speaker: ABRAHAM

lines.value: SAMPSON
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: Draw, if you be men. Gregory, remember thy swashing blow.
lines.speaker: SAMPSON

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Part, fools!
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Put up your swords; you know not what you do.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: TYBALT
lines.speaker: TYBALT

lines.value: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?
lines.speaker: TYBALT

lines.value: Turn thee, Benvolio, look upon thy death.
lines.speaker: TYBALT

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: I do but keep the peace: put up thy sword,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Or manage it to part these men with me.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: TYBALT
lines.speaker: TYBALT

lines.value: What, drawn, and talk of peace! I hate the word,
lines.speaker: TYBALT

lines.value: As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee:
lines.speaker: TYBALT

lines.value: Have at thee, coward!
lines.speaker: TYBALT

lines.value: First Citizen
lines.speaker: First Citizen

lines.value: Clubs, bills, and partisans! strike! beat them down!
lines.speaker: First Citizen

lines.value: Down with the Capulets! down with the Montagues!
lines.speaker: First Citizen

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: What noise is this? Give me my long sword, ho!
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: A crutch, a crutch! why call you for a sword?
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: My sword, I say! Old Montague is come,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: And flourishes his blade in spite of me.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: MONTAGUE
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Thou villain Capulet,--Hold me not, let me go.
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: LADY MONTAGUE
lines.speaker: LADY MONTAGUE

lines.value: Thou shalt not stir a foot to seek a foe.
lines.speaker: LADY MONTAGUE

lines.value: PRINCE
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel,--
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Will they not hear? What, ho! you men, you beasts,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: That quench the fire of your pernicious rage
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: With purple fountains issuing from your veins,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: On pain of torture, from those bloody hands
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Throw your mistemper'd weapons to the ground,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: And hear the sentence of your moved prince.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Three civil brawls, bred of an airy word,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: By thee, old Capulet, and Montague,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Have thrice disturb'd the quiet of our streets,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: And made Verona's ancient citizens
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Cast by their grave beseeming ornaments,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: To wield old partisans, in hands as old,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Canker'd with peace, to part your canker'd hate:
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: If ever you disturb our streets again,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: For this time, all the rest depart away:
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: You Capulet; shall go along with me:
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: And, Montague, come you this afternoon,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: To know our further pleasure in this case,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: To old Free-town, our common judgment-place.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Once more, on pain of death, all men depart.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: MONTAGUE
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Who set this ancient quarrel new abroach?
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Speak, nephew, were you by when it began?
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Here were the servants of your adversary,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: And yours, close fighting ere I did approach:
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: I drew to part them: in the instant came
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: The fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepared,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Which, as he breathed defiance to my ears,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: He swung about his head and cut the winds,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Who nothing hurt withal hiss'd him in scorn:
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: While we were interchanging thrusts and blows,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Came more and more and fought on part and part,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Till the prince came, who parted either part.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: LADY MONTAGUE
lines.speaker: LADY MONTAGUE

lines.value: O, where is Romeo? saw you him to-day?
lines.speaker: LADY MONTAGUE

lines.value: Right glad I am he was not at this fray.
lines.speaker: LADY MONTAGUE

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Madam, an hour before the worshipp'd sun
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Peer'd forth the golden window of the east,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: A troubled mind drave me to walk abroad;
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Where, underneath the grove of sycamore
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: That westward rooteth from the city's side,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: So early walking did I see your son:
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Towards him I made, but he was ware of me
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: And stole into the covert of the wood:
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: I, measuring his affections by my own,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: That most are busied when they're most alone,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Pursued my humour not pursuing his,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: And gladly shunn'd who gladly fled from me.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: MONTAGUE
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Many a morning hath he there been seen,
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: With tears augmenting the fresh morning dew.
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs;
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: But all so soon as the all-cheering sun
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Should in the furthest east begin to draw
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: The shady curtains from Aurora's bed,
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Away from the light steals home my heavy son,
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: And private in his chamber pens himself,
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Shuts up his windows, locks far daylight out
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: And makes himself an artificial night:
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Black and portentous must this humour prove,
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Unless good counsel may the cause remove.
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: MONTAGUE
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: I neither know it nor can learn of him.
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Have you importuned him by any means?
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: MONTAGUE
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Both by myself and many other friends:
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: But he, his own affections' counsellor,
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Is to himself--I will not say how true--
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: But to himself so secret and so close,
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: So far from sounding and discovery,
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: As is the bud bit with an envious worm,
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air,
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Or dedicate his beauty to the sun.
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow.
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: We would as willingly give cure as know.
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: See, where he comes: so please you, step aside;
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: I'll know his grievance, or be much denied.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: MONTAGUE
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: I would thou wert so happy by thy stay,
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: To hear true shrift. Come, madam, let's away.
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Good-morrow, cousin.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Is the day so young?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: But new struck nine.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Ay me! sad hours seem long.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Was that my father that went hence so fast?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Not having that, which, having, makes them short.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: In love?
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Out--
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Of love?
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Out of her favour, where I am in love.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Alas, that love, so gentle in his view,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Should be so tyrannous and rough in proof!
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Alas, that love, whose view is muffled still,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Should, without eyes, see pathways to his will!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Where shall we dine? O me! What fray was here?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Here's much to do with hate, but more with love.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Why, then, O brawling love! O loving hate!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O any thing, of nothing first create!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O heavy lightness! serious vanity!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: sick health!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: This love feel I, that feel no love in this.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Dost thou not laugh?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: No, coz, I rather weep.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Good heart, at what?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: At thy good heart's oppression.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Why, such is love's transgression.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Griefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Which thou wilt propagate, to have it prest
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: With more of thine: this love that thou hast shown
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Love is a smoke raised with the fume of sighs;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Being vex'd a sea nourish'd with lovers' tears:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: What is it else? a madness most discreet,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: A choking gall and a preserving sweet.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Farewell, my coz.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Soft! I will go along;
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: An if you leave me so, you do me wrong.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Tut, I have lost myself; I am not here;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: This is not Romeo, he's some other where.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: What, shall I groan and tell thee?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Groan! why, no.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: But sadly tell me who.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Bid a sick man in sadness make his will:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Ah, word ill urged to one that is so ill!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: I aim'd so near, when I supposed you loved.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: A right good mark-man! And she's fair I love.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Well, in that hit you miss: she'll not be hit
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: With Cupid's arrow; she hath Dian's wit;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And, in strong proof of chastity well arm'd,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: From love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: She will not stay the siege of loving terms,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Nor bide the encounter of assailing eyes,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Nor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O, she is rich in beauty, only poor,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: That when she dies with beauty dies her store.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: For beauty starved with her severity
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: To merit bliss by making me despair:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Do I live dead that live to tell it now.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Be ruled by me, forget to think of her.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O, teach me how I should forget to think.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: By giving liberty unto thine eyes;
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Examine other beauties.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: 'Tis the way
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: To call hers exquisite, in question more:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Being black put us in mind they hide the fair;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: He that is strucken blind cannot forget
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: The precious treasure of his eyesight lost:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Show me a mistress that is passing fair,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: What doth her beauty serve, but as a note
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Prick'd from the lazy finger of a maid;
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Her chariot is an empty hazel-nut
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Made by the joiner squirrel or old grub,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Time out o' mind the fairies' coachmakers.
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: And in this state she gallops night by night
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Through lovers' brains, and then they dream of love;
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: O'er courtiers' knees, that dream on court'sies straight,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: O'er lawyers' fingers, who straight dream on fees,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: O'er ladies ' lips, who straight on kisses dream,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are:
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier's nose,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: And then dreams he of smelling out a suit;
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig's tail
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Tickling a parson's nose as a' lies asleep,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Then dreams, he of another benefice:
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Sometime she driveth o'er a soldier's neck,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Of breaches, ambuscadoes, Spanish blades,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Of healths five-fathom deep; and then anon
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: And sleeps again. This is that very Mab
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: And bakes the elflocks in foul sluttish hairs,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh:
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied;
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Cry but 'Ay me!' pronounce but 'love' and 'dove;'
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: One nick-name for her purblind son and heir,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Young Adam Cupid, he that shot so trim,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: When King Cophetua loved the beggar-maid!
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not;
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: The ape is dead, and I must conjure him.
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: I conjure thee by Rosaline's bright eyes,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: By her high forehead and her scarlet lip,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: By her fine foot, straight leg and quivering thigh
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: And the demesnes that there adjacent lie,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: That in thy likeness thou appear to us!
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: And if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: MERCUTIO
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: This cannot anger him: 'twould anger him
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: To raise a spirit in his mistress' circle
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Of some strange nature, letting it there stand
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Till she had laid it and conjured it down;
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: That were some spite: my invocation
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Is fair and honest, and in his mistres s' name
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: I conjure only but to raise up him.
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Come, he hath hid himself among these trees,
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: To be consorted with the humorous night:
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Blind is his love and best befits the dark.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: MERCUTIO
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Now will he sit under a medlar tree,
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: As maids call medlars, when they laugh alone.
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Romeo, that she were, O, that she were
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: An open et caetera, thou a poperin pear!
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Romeo, good night: I'll to my truckle-bed;
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: This field-bed is too cold for me to sleep:
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: Come, shall we go?
lines.speaker: MERCUTIO

lines.value: BENVOLIO
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: Go, then; for 'tis in vain
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: To seek him here that means not to be found.
lines.speaker: BENVOLIO

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: He jests at scars that never felt a wound.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: But, soft! what light through yonder window breaks?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Who is already sick and pale with grief,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: That thou her maid art far more fair than she:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Be not her maid, since she is envious;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Her vestal livery is but sick and green
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And none but fools do wear it; cast it off.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: It is my lady, O, it is my love!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O, that she knew she were!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: She speaks yet she says nothing: what of that?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Her eye discourses; I will answer it.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I am too bold, 'tis not to me she speaks:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Having some business, do entreat her eyes
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: To twinkle in their spheres till they return.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: What if her eyes were there, they in her head?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: As daylight doth a lamp; her eyes in heaven
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Would through the airy region stream so bright
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: That birds would sing and think it were not night.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: See, how she leans her cheek upon her hand!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O, that I were a glove upon that hand,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: That I might touch that cheek!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Ay me!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: She speaks:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O, speak again, bright angel! for thou art
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: As glorious to this night, being o'er my head
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: As is a winged messenger of heaven
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Unto the white-upturned wondering eyes
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Of mortals that fall back to gaze on him
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: When he bestrides the lazy-pacing clouds
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And sails upon the bosom of the air.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O Romeo, Romeo! wherefore art thou Romeo?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Deny thy father and refuse thy name;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And I'll no longer be a Capulet.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: [Aside]  Shall I hear more, or shall I speak at this?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: 'Tis but thy name that is my enemy;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Thou art thyself, though not a Montague.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What's Montague? it is nor hand, nor foot,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Belonging to a man. O, be some other name!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What's in a name? that which we call a rose
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: By any other name would smell as sweet;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: So Romeo would, were he not Romeo call'd,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Retain that dear perfection which he owes
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Without that title. Romeo, doff thy name,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And for that name which is no part of thee
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Take all myself.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I take thee at thy word:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Call me but love, and I'll be new baptized;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Henceforth I never will be Romeo.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What man art thou that thus bescreen'd in night
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: So stumblest on my counsel?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: By a name
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I know not how to tell thee who I am:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Because it is an enemy to thee;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Had I it written, I would tear the word.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Of that tongue's utterance, yet I know the sound:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Art thou not Romeo and a Montague?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Neither, fair saint, if either thee dislike.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: How camest thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: The orchard walls are high and hard to climb,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And the place death, considering who thou art,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: If any of my kinsmen find thee here.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: With love's light wings did I o'er-perch these walls;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: For stony limits cannot hold love out,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And what love can do that dares love attempt;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Therefore thy kinsmen are no let to me.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: If they do see thee, they will murder thee.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Than twenty of their swords: look thou but sweet,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And I am proof against their enmity.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I would not for the world they saw thee here.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I have night's cloak to hide me from their sight;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And but thou love me, let them find me here:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: My life were better ended by their hate,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Than death prorogued, wanting of thy love.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: By whose direction found'st thou out this place?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: By love, who first did prompt me to inquire;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: He lent me counsel and I lent him eyes.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I am no pilot; yet, wert thou as far
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: As that vast shore wash'd with the farthest sea,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I would adventure for such merchandise.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Thou know'st the mask of night is on my face,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: For that which thou hast heard me speak to-night
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Fain would I dwell on form, fain, fain deny
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What I have spoke: but farewell compliment!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Dost thou love me? I know thou wilt say 'Ay,'
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And I will take thy word: yet if thou swear'st,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Thou mayst prove false; at lovers' perjuries
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Then say, Jove laughs. O gentle Romeo,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I'll frown and be perverse an say thee nay,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: So thou wilt woo; but else, not for the world.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: In truth, fair Montague, I am too fond,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And therefore thou mayst think my 'havior light:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: But trust me, gentleman, I'll prove more true
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Than those that have more cunning to be strange.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I should have been more strange, I must confess,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: But that thou overheard'st, ere I was ware,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: My true love's passion: therefore pardon me,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And not impute this yielding to light love,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Which the dark night hath so discovered.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Lady, by yonder blessed moon I swear
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops--
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O, swear not by the moon, the inconstant moon,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: That monthly changes in her circled orb,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: What shall I swear by?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Do not swear at all;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Which is the god of my idolatry,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And I'll believe thee.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: If my heart's dear love--
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Well, do not swear: although I joy in thee,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I have no joy of this contract to-night:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: It is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Ere one can say 'It lightens.' Sweet, good night!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: This bud of love, by summer's ripening breath,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Good night, good night! as sweet repose and rest
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Come to thy heart as that within my breast!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What satisfaction canst thou have to-night?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And yet I would it were to give again.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Wouldst thou withdraw it? for what purpose, love?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: But to be frank, and give it thee again.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And yet I wish but for the thing I have:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: My bounty is as boundless as the sea,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: My love as deep; the more I give to thee,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: The more I have, for both are infinite.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I hear some noise within; dear love, adieu!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Anon, good nurse! Sweet Montague, be true.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Stay but a little, I will come again.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O blessed, blessed night! I am afeard.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Being in night, all this is but a dream,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Too flattering-sweet to be substantial.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: If that thy bent of love be honourable,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Thy purpose marriage, send me word to-morrow,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: By one that I'll procure to come to thee,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And all my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And follow thee my lord throughout the world.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: [Within]  Madam!
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I come, anon.--But if thou mean'st not well,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I do beseech thee--
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: [Within]  Madam!
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: By and by, I come:--
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To cease thy suit, and leave me to my grief:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To-morrow will I send.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: So thrive my soul--
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: A thousand times good night!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: A thousand times the worse, to want thy light.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Love goes toward love, as schoolboys from
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: their books,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Hist! Romeo, hist! O, for a falconer's voice,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To lure this tassel-gentle back again!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: With repetition of my Romeo's name.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: It is my soul that calls upon my name:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Like softest music to attending ears!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Romeo!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: My dear?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: At what o'clock to-morrow
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Shall I send to thee?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: At the hour of nine.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I will not fail: 'tis twenty years till then.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I have forgot why I did call thee back.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Let me stand here till thou remember it.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I shall forget, to have thee still stand there,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Remembering how I love thy company.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And I'll still stay, to have thee still forget,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Forgetting any other home but this.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: 'Tis almost morning; I would have thee gone:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And yet no further than a wanton's bird;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Who lets it hop a little from her hand,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And with a silk thread plucks it back again,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: So loving-jealous of his liberty.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I would I were thy bird.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Sweet, so would I:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Good night, good night! parting is such
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: sweet sorrow,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: That I shall say good night till it be morrow.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Hence will I to my ghostly father's cell,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: His help to crave, and my dear hap to tell.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: The grey-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Chequering the eastern clouds with streaks of light,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And flecked darkness like a drunkard reels
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: From forth day's path and Titan's fiery wheels:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: The day to cheer and night's dank dew to dry,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: I must up-fill this osier cage of ours
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: With baleful weeds and precious-juiced flowers.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: The earth that's nature's mother is her tomb;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: What is her burying grave that is her womb,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And from her womb children of divers kind
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: We sucking on her natural bosom find,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Many for many virtues excellent,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: None but for some and yet all different.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: O, mickle is the powerful grace that lies
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: For nought so vile that on the earth doth live
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: But to the earth some special good doth give,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Nor aught so good but strain'd from that fair use
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And vice sometimes by action dignified.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Within the infant rind of this small flower
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Poison hath residence and medicine power:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Being tasted, slays all senses with the heart.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Two such opposed kings encamp them still
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: In man as well as herbs, grace and rude will;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And where the worser is predominant,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Or, if sour woe delights in fellowship
