lines.value: And needly will be rank'd with other griefs,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Why follow'd not, when she said 'Tybalt's dead,'
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Thy father, or thy mother, nay, or both,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Which modern lamentations might have moved?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: But with a rear-ward following Tybalt's death,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: 'Romeo is banished,' to speak that word,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: All slain, all dead. 'Romeo is banished!'
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: There is no end, no limit, measure, bound,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: In that word's death; no words can that woe sound.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Where is my father, and my mother, nurse?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Weeping and wailing over Tybalt's corse:
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Will you go to them? I will bring you thither.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Wash they his wounds with tears: mine shall be spent,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: When theirs are dry, for Romeo's banishment.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Take up those cords: poor ropes, you are beguiled,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Both you and I; for Romeo is exiled:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: He made you for a highway to my bed;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: But I, a maid, die maiden-widowed.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Come, cords, come, nurse; I'll to my wedding-bed;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Hie to your chamber: I'll find Romeo
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: To comfort you: I wot well where he is.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Hark ye, your Romeo will be here at night:
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: I'll to him; he is hid at Laurence' cell.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O, find him! give this ring to my true knight,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And bid him come to take his last farewell.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Romeo, come forth; come forth, thou fearful man:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Affliction is enamour'd of thy parts,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And thou art wedded to calamity.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Father, what news? what is the prince's doom?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: What sorrow craves acquaintance at my hand,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: That I yet know not?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Too familiar
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Is my dear son with such sour company:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: I bring thee tidings of the prince's doom.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: What less than dooms-day is the prince's doom?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: A gentler judgment vanish'd from his lips,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Not body's death, but body's banishment.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Ha, banishment! be merciful, say 'death;'
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: For exile hath more terror in his look,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Much more than death: do not say 'banishment.'
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Hence from Verona art thou banished:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: There is no world without Verona walls,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: But purgatory, torture, hell itself.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Hence-banished is banish'd from the world,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And world's exile is death: then banished,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Is death mis-term'd: calling death banishment,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Thou cutt'st my head off with a golden axe,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: O deadly sin! O rude unthankfulness!
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thy fault our law calls death; but the kind prince,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Taking thy part, hath rush'd aside the law,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And turn'd that black word death to banishment:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: This is dear mercy, and thou seest it not.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: 'Tis torture, and not mercy: heaven is here,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Where Juliet lives; and every cat and dog
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And little mouse, every unworthy thing,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Live here in heaven and may look on her;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: But Romeo may not: more validity,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: More honourable state, more courtship lives
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: In carrion-flies than Romeo: they my seize
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: On the white wonder of dear Juliet's hand
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And steal immortal blessing from her lips,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Who even in pure and vestal modesty,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Still blush, as thinking their own kisses sin;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: But Romeo may not; he is banished:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Flies may do this, but I from this must fly:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: They are free men, but I am banished.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And say'st thou yet that exile is not death?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Hadst thou no poison mix'd, no sharp-ground knife,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: No sudden mean of death, though ne'er so mean,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: But 'banished' to kill me?--'banished'?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O friar, the damned use that word in hell;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Howlings attend it: how hast thou the heart,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Being a divine, a ghostly confessor,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: A sin-absolver, and my friend profess'd,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: To mangle me with that word 'banished'?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thou fond mad man, hear me but speak a word.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O, thou wilt speak again of banishment.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: I'll give thee armour to keep off that word:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Adversity's sweet milk, philosophy,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: To comfort thee, though thou art banished.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Yet 'banished'? Hang up philosophy!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Unless philosophy can make a Juliet,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Displant a town, reverse a prince's doom,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: It helps not, it prevails not: talk no more.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: O, then I see that madmen have no ears.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: How should they, when that wise men have no eyes?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Wert thou as young as I, Juliet thy love,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: An hour but married, Tybalt murdered,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Doting like me and like me banished,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Then mightst thou speak, then mightst thou tear thy hair,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And fall upon the ground, as I do now,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Taking the measure of an unmade grave.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Arise; one knocks; good Romeo, hide thyself.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Not I; unless the breath of heartsick groans,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Mist-like, infold me from the search of eyes.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Hark, how they knock! Who's there? Romeo, arise;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thou wilt be taken. Stay awhile! Stand up;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Run to my study. By and by! God's will,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: What simpleness is this! I come, I come!
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Who knocks so hard? whence come you? what's your will?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: [Within]  Let me come in, and you shall know
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: my errand;
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: I come from Lady Juliet.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Welcome, then.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: O holy friar, O, tell me, holy friar,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Where is my lady's lord, where's Romeo?
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: There on the ground, with his own tears made drunk.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: O, he is even in my mistress' case,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Just in her case! O woful sympathy!
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Piteous predicament! Even so lies she,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Stand up, stand up; stand, and you be a man:
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: For Juliet's sake, for her sake, rise and stand;
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Why should you fall into so deep an O?
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Nurse!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Ah sir! ah sir! Well, death's the end of all.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Spakest thou of Juliet? how is it with her?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Doth she not think me an old murderer,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Now I have stain'd the childhood of our joy
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: With blood removed but little from her own?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Where is she? and how doth she? and what says
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: My conceal'd lady to our cancell'd love?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: O, she says nothing, sir, but weeps and weeps;
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: And now falls on her bed; and then starts up,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: And Tybalt calls; and then on Romeo cries,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: And then down falls again.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: As if that name,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Shot from the deadly level of a gun,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Did murder her; as that name's cursed hand
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Murder'd her kinsman. O, tell me, friar, tell me,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: In what vile part of this anatomy
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Doth my name lodge? tell me, that I may sack
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: The hateful mansion.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Hold thy desperate hand:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Art thou a man? thy form cries out thou art:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thy tears are womanish; thy wild acts denote
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: The unreasonable fury of a beast:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Unseemly woman in a seeming man!
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Or ill-beseeming beast in seeming both!
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thou hast amazed me: by my holy order,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: I thought thy disposition better temper'd.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Hast thou slain Tybalt? wilt thou slay thyself?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And stay thy lady too that lives in thee,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: By doing damned hate upon thyself?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Why rail'st thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Since birth, and heaven, and earth, all three do meet
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: In thee at once; which thou at once wouldst lose.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape, thy love, thy wit;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Which, like a usurer, abound'st in all,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And usest none in that true use indeed
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Which should bedeck thy shape, thy love, thy wit:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thy noble shape is but a form of wax,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Digressing from the valour of a man;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thy dear love sworn but hollow perjury,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Killing that love which thou hast vow'd to cherish;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thy wit, that ornament to shape and love,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Misshapen in the conduct of them both,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Like powder in a skitless soldier's flask,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Is set afire by thine own ignorance,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And thou dismember'd with thine own defence.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: What, rouse thee, man! thy Juliet is alive,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: For whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: There art thou happy: Tybalt would kill thee,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: But thou slew'st Tybalt; there are thou happy too:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: The law that threaten'd death becomes thy friend
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And turns it to exile; there art thou happy:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: A pack of blessings lights up upon thy back;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Happiness courts thee in her best array;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: But, like a misbehaved and sullen wench,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thou pout'st upon thy fortune and thy love:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Take heed, take heed, for such die miserable.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Ascend her chamber, hence and comfort her:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: But look thou stay not till the watch be set,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: For then thou canst not pass to Mantua;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Where thou shalt live, till we can find a time
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: To blaze your marriage, reconcile your friends,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Beg pardon of the prince, and call thee back
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: With twenty hundred thousand times more joy
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Than thou went'st forth in lamentation.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Go before, nurse: commend me to thy lady;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And bid her hasten all the house to bed,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Romeo is coming.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: O Lord, I could have stay'd here all the night
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: To hear good counsel: O, what learning is!
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: My lord, I'll tell my lady you will come.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Here, sir, a ring she bid me give you, sir:
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Hie you, make haste, for it grows very late.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: How well my comfort is revived by this!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Go hence; good night; and here stands all your state:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Either be gone before the watch be set,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Or by the break of day disguised from hence:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Sojourn in Mantua; I'll find out your man,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And he shall signify from time to time
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Every good hap to you that chances here:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Give me thy hand; 'tis late: farewell; good night.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: But that a joy past joy calls out on me,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: It were a grief, so brief to part with thee: Farewell.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Things have fall'n out, sir, so unluckily,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: That we have had no time to move our daughter:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Look you, she loved her kinsman Tybalt dearly,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: And so did I:--Well, we were born to die.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: 'Tis very late, she'll not come down to-night:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: I promise you, but for your company,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: I would have been a-bed an hour ago.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: These times of woe afford no time to woo.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Madam, good night: commend me to your daughter.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: I will, and know her mind early to-morrow;
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: To-night she is mew'd up to her heaviness.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Sir Paris, I will make a desperate tender
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Of my child's love: I think she will be ruled
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: In all respects by me; nay, more, I doubt it not.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Wife, go you to her ere you go to bed;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Acquaint her here of my son Paris' love;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: And bid her, mark you me, on Wednesday next--
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: But, soft! what day is this?
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Monday, my lord,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Monday! ha, ha! Well, Wednesday is too soon,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: O' Thursday let it be: o' Thursday, tell her,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: She shall be married to this noble earl.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Will you be ready? do you like this haste?
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: We'll keep no great ado,--a friend or two;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: For, hark you, Tybalt being slain so late,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: It may be thought we held him carelessly,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Being our kinsman, if we revel much:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Therefore we'll have some half a dozen friends,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: And there an end. But what say you to Thursday?
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: My lord, I would that Thursday were to-morrow.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Well get you gone: o' Thursday be it, then.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Prepare her, wife, against this wedding-day.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Farewell, my lord. Light to my chamber, ho!
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Afore me! it is so very very late,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: That we may call it early by and by.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Good night.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Wilt thou be gone? it is not yet near day:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: It was the nightingale, and not the lark,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nightly she sings on yon pomegranate-tree:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Believe me, love, it was the nightingale.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: It was the lark, the herald of the morn,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: No nightingale: look, love, what envious streaks
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I must be gone and live, or stay and die.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Yon light is not day-light, I know it, I:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: It is some meteor that the sun exhales,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To be to thee this night a torch-bearer,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And light thee on thy way to Mantua:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Therefore stay yet; thou need'st not to be gone.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Let me be ta'en, let me be put to death;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I am content, so thou wilt have it so.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I'll say yon grey is not the morning's eye,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: 'Tis but the pale reflex of Cynthia's brow;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Nor that is not the lark, whose notes do beat
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: The vaulty heaven so high above our heads:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I have more care to stay than will to go:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Come, death, and welcome! Juliet wills it so.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: How is't, my soul? let's talk; it is not day.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: It is, it is: hie hence, be gone, away!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: It is the lark that sings so out of tune,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Straining harsh discords and unpleasing sharps.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Some say the lark makes sweet division;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: This doth not so, for she divideth us:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Some say the lark and loathed toad change eyes,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O, now I would they had changed voices too!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Since arm from arm that voice doth us affray,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Hunting thee hence with hunt's-up to the day,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O, now be gone; more light and light it grows.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: More light and light; more dark and dark our woes!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Madam!
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nurse?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Your lady mother is coming to your chamber:
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: The day is broke; be wary, look about.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Then, window, let day in, and let life out.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Farewell, farewell! one kiss, and I'll descend.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Art thou gone so? love, lord, ay, husband, friend!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I must hear from thee every day in the hour,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: For in a minute there are many days:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O, by this count I shall be much in years
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Ere I again behold my Romeo!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Farewell!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I will omit no opportunity
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: That may convey my greetings, love, to thee.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O think'st thou we shall ever meet again?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I doubt it not; and all these woes shall serve
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: For sweet discourses in our time to come.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O God, I have an ill-divining soul!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Methinks I see thee, now thou art below,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: As one dead in the bottom of a tomb:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Either my eyesight fails, or thou look'st pale.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And trust me, love, in my eye so do you:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Dry sorrow drinks our blood. Adieu, adieu!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O fortune, fortune! all men call thee fickle:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: If thou art fickle, what dost thou with him.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: That is renown'd for faith? Be fickle, fortune;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: For then, I hope, thou wilt not keep him long,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: But send him back.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: [Within]         Ho, daughter! are you up?
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Who is't that calls? is it my lady mother?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Is she not down so late, or up so early?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What unaccustom'd cause procures her hither?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Why, how now, Juliet!
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Madam, I am not well.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Evermore weeping for your cousin's death?
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: What, wilt thou wash him from his grave with tears?
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: An if thou couldst, thou couldst not make him live;
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Therefore, have done: some grief shows much of love;
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: But much of grief shows still some want of wit.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Yet let me weep for such a feeling loss.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: So shall you feel the loss, but not the friend
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Which you weep for.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Feeling so the loss,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Cannot choose but ever weep the friend.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Well, girl, thou weep'st not so much for his death,
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: As that the villain lives which slaughter'd him.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What villain madam?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: That same villain, Romeo.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: [Aside]  Villain and he be many miles asunder.--
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: God Pardon him! I do, with all my heart;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And yet no man like he doth grieve my heart.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: That is, because the traitor murderer lives.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Ay, madam, from the reach of these my hands:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Would none but I might venge my cousin's death!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: We will have vengeance for it, fear thou not:
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Then weep no more. I'll send to one in Mantua,
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Where that same banish'd runagate doth live,
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Shall give him such an unaccustom'd dram,
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: That he shall soon keep Tybalt company:
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: And then, I hope, thou wilt be satisfied.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Indeed, I never shall be satisfied
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: With Romeo, till I behold him--dead--
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Is my poor heart for a kinsman vex'd.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Madam, if you could find out but a man
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To bear a poison, I would temper it;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: That Romeo should, upon receipt thereof,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Soon sleep in quiet. O, how my heart abhors
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To hear him named, and cannot come to him.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To wreak the love I bore my cousin
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Upon his body that slaughter'd him!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Find thou the means, and I'll find such a man.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: But now I'll tell thee joyful tidings, girl.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And joy comes well in such a needy time:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What are they, I beseech your ladyship?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Well, well, thou hast a careful father, child;
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: One who, to put thee from thy heaviness,
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Hath sorted out a sudden day of joy,
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: That thou expect'st not nor I look'd not for.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Madam, in happy time, what day is that?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Marry, my child, early next Thursday morn,
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: The gallant, young and noble gentleman,
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: The County Paris, at Saint Peter's Church,
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Now, by Saint Peter's Church and Peter too,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: He shall not make me there a joyful bride.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I wonder at this haste; that I must wed
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Ere he, that should be husband, comes to woo.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I pray you, tell my lord and father, madam,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I will not marry yet; and, when I do, I swear,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: It shall be Romeo, whom you know I hate,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Rather than Paris. These are news indeed!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Here comes your father; tell him so yourself,
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: And see how he will take it at your hands.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: When the sun sets, the air doth drizzle dew;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: But for the sunset of my brother's son
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: It rains downright.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: How now! a conduit, girl? what, still in tears?
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Evermore showering? In one little body
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Thou counterfeit'st a bark, a sea, a wind;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: For still thy eyes, which I may call the sea,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Do ebb and flow with tears; the bark thy body is,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Sailing in this salt flood; the winds, thy sighs;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Who, raging with thy tears, and they with them,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Without a sudden calm, will overset
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Thy tempest-tossed body. How now, wife!
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Have you deliver'd to her our decree?
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Ay, sir; but she will none, she gives you thanks.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: I would the fool were married to her grave!
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Soft! take me with you, take me with you, wife.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: How! will she none? doth she not give us thanks?
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Is she not proud? doth she not count her blest,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Unworthy as she is, that we have wrought
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: So worthy a gentleman to be her bridegroom?
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Not proud, you have; but thankful, that you have:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Proud can I never be of what I hate;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: But thankful even for hate, that is meant love.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: How now, how now, chop-logic! What is this?
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: 'Proud,' and 'I thank you,' and 'I thank you not;'
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: And yet 'not proud,' mistress minion, you,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Thank me no thankings, nor, proud me no prouds,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: But fettle your fine joints 'gainst Thursday next,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: To go with Paris to Saint Peter's Church,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Or I will drag thee on a hurdle thither.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Out, you green-sickness carrion! out, you baggage!
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: You tallow-face!
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Fie, fie! what, are you mad?
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Good father, I beseech you on my knees,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Hear me with patience but to speak a word.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Hang thee, young baggage! disobedient wretch!
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: I tell thee what: get thee to church o' Thursday,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Or never after look me in the face:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Speak not, reply not, do not answer me;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: My fingers itch. Wife, we scarce thought us blest
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: That God had lent us but this only child;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: But now I see this one is one too much,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: And that we have a curse in having her:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Out on her, hilding!
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: God in heaven bless her!
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: You are to blame, my lord, to rate her so.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: And why, my lady wisdom? hold your tongue,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Good prudence; smatter with your gossips, go.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: I speak no treason.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: O, God ye god-den.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: May not one speak?
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Peace, you mumbling fool!
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Utter your gravity o'er a gossip's bowl;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: For here we need it not.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: You are too hot.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: God's bread! it makes me mad:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Day, night, hour, tide, time, work, play,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Alone, in company, still my care hath been
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: To have her match'd: and having now provided
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: A gentleman of noble parentage,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Of fair demesnes, youthful, and nobly train'd,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Stuff'd, as they say, with honourable parts,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Proportion'd as one's thought would wish a man;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: And then to have a wretched puling fool,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: A whining mammet, in her fortune's tender,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: To answer 'I'll not wed; I cannot love,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: I am too young; I pray you, pardon me.'
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: But, as you will not wed, I'll pardon you:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Graze where you will you shall not house with me:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Look to't, think on't, I do not use to jest.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Thursday is near; lay hand on heart, advise:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: An you be mine, I'll give you to my friend;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: And you be not, hang, beg, starve, die in
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: the streets,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: For, by my soul, I'll ne'er acknowledge thee,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Nor what is mine shall never do thee good:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Trust to't, bethink you; I'll not be forsworn.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Is there no pity sitting in the clouds,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: That sees into the bottom of my grief?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O, sweet my mother, cast me not away!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Delay this marriage for a month, a week;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Or, if you do not, make the bridal bed
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Talk not to me, for I'll not speak a word:
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O God!--O nurse, how shall this be prevented?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: How shall that faith return again to earth,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Unless that husband send it me from heaven
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: By leaving earth? comfort me, counsel me.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Alack, alack, that heaven should practise stratagems
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Upon so soft a subject as myself!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What say'st thou? hast thou not a word of joy?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Some comfort, nurse.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Faith, here it is.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Romeo is banish'd; and all the world to nothing,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: That he dares ne'er come back to challenge you;
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Or, if he do, it needs must be by stealth.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Then, since the case so stands as now it doth,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: I think it best you married with the county.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: O, he's a lovely gentleman!
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Romeo's a dishclout to him: an eagle, madam,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Hath not so green, so quick, so fair an eye
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: As Paris hath. Beshrew my very heart,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: I think you are happy in this second match,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: For it excels your first: or if it did not,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Your first is dead; or 'twere as good he were,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: As living here and you no use of him.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Speakest thou from thy heart?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: And from my soul too;
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Or else beshrew them both.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Amen!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: What?
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Well, thou hast comforted me marvellous much.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Go in: and tell my lady I am gone,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Having displeased my father, to Laurence' cell,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To make confession and to be absolved.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Marry, I will; and this is wisely done.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Ancient damnation! O most wicked fiend!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Is it more sin to wish me thus forsworn,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Or to dispraise my lord with that same tongue
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Which she hath praised him with above compare
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: So many thousand times? Go, counsellor;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Thou and my bosom henceforth shall be twain.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I'll to the friar, to know his remedy:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: If all else fail, myself have power to die.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: On Thursday, sir? the time is very short.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: My father Capulet will have it so;
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: And I am nothing slow to slack his haste.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: You say you do not know the lady's mind:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Uneven is the course, I like it not.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Immoderately she weeps for Tybalt's death,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: And therefore have I little talk'd of love;
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: For Venus smiles not in a house of tears.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Now, sir, her father counts it dangerous
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: That she doth give her sorrow so much sway,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: And in his wisdom hastes our marriage,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: To stop the inundation of her tears;
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Which, too much minded by herself alone,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: May be put from her by society:
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Now do you know the reason of this haste.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: [Aside]  I would I knew not why it should be slow'd.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Look, sir, here comes the lady towards my cell.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Happily met, my lady and my wife!
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: That may be must be, love, on Thursday next.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What must be shall be.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: That's a certain text.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Come you to make confession to this father?
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To answer that, I should confess to you.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Do not deny to him that you love me.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I will confess to you that I love him.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: So will ye, I am sure, that you love me.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: If I do so, it will be of more price,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Being spoke behind your back, than to your face.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Poor soul, thy face is much abused with tears.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: The tears have got small victory by that;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: For it was bad enough before their spite.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Thou wrong'st it, more than tears, with that report.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: That is no slander, sir, which is a truth;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And what I spake, I spake it to my face.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slander'd it.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: It may be so, for it is not mine own.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Are you at leisure, holy father, now;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Or shall I come to you at evening mass?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: My lord, we must entreat the time alone.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: God shield I should disturb devotion!
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye:
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Till then, adieu; and keep this holy kiss.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O shut the door! and when thou hast done so,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Come weep with me; past hope, past cure, past help!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Ah, Juliet, I already know thy grief;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: It strains me past the compass of my wits:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: I hear thou must, and nothing may prorogue it,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: On Thursday next be married to this county.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Tell me not, friar, that thou hear'st of this,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Unless thou tell me how I may prevent it:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: If, in thy wisdom, thou canst give no help,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Do thou but call my resolution wise,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And with this knife I'll help it presently.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: God join'd my heart and Romeo's, thou our hands;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And ere this hand, by thee to Romeo seal'd,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Shall be the label to another deed,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Or my true heart with treacherous revolt
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Turn to another, this shall slay them both:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Therefore, out of thy long-experienced time,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Give me some present counsel, or, behold,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: 'Twixt my extremes and me this bloody knife
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Shall play the umpire, arbitrating that
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Which the commission of thy years and art
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Could to no issue of true honour bring.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Be not so long to speak; I long to die,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: If what thou speak'st speak not of remedy.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Hold, daughter: I do spy a kind of hope,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Which craves as desperate an execution.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: As that is desperate which we would prevent.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: If, rather than to marry County Paris,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thou hast the strength of will to slay thyself,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Then is it likely thou wilt undertake
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: A thing like death to chide away this shame,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: That copest with death himself to scape from it:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And, if thou darest, I'll give thee remedy.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O, bid me leap, rather than marry Paris,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: From off the battlements of yonder tower;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Or walk in thievish ways; or bid me lurk
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Where serpents are; chain me with roaring bears;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Or shut me nightly in a charnel-house,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O'er-cover'd quite with dead men's rattling bones,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: With reeky shanks and yellow chapless skulls;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Or bid me go into a new-made grave
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And hide me with a dead man in his shroud;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Things that, to hear them told, have made me tremble;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And I will do it without fear or doubt,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To live an unstain'd wife to my sweet love.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Hold, then; go home, be merry, give consent
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: To marry Paris: Wednesday is to-morrow:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: To-morrow night look that thou lie alone;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Let not thy nurse lie with thee in thy chamber:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Take thou this vial, being then in bed,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And this distilled liquor drink thou off;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: When presently through all thy veins shall run
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: A cold and drowsy humour, for no pulse
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Shall keep his native progress, but surcease:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: No warmth, no breath, shall testify thou livest;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: The roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: To paly ashes, thy eyes' windows fall,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Like death, when he shuts up the day of life;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Each part, deprived of supple government,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Shall, stiff and stark and cold, appear like death:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And in this borrow'd likeness of shrunk death
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thou shalt continue two and forty hours,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And then awake as from a pleasant sleep.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Now, when the bridegroom in the morning comes
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: To rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Then, as the manner of our country is,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: In thy best robes uncover'd on the bier
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: In the mean time, against thou shalt awake,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Shall Romeo by my letters know our drift,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And hither shall he come: and he and I
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Will watch thy waking, and that very night
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And this shall free thee from this present shame;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: If no inconstant toy, nor womanish fear,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Abate thy valour in the acting it.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Give me, give me! O, tell not me of fear!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Hold; get you gone, be strong and prosperous
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: In this resolve: I'll send a friar with speed
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: To Mantua, with my letters to thy lord.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Love give me strength! and strength shall help afford.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Farewell, dear father!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: So many guests invite as here are writ.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Sirrah, go hire me twenty cunning cooks.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Second Servant
lines.speaker: Second Servant

lines.value: You shall have none ill, sir; for I'll try if they
lines.speaker: Second Servant

lines.value: can lick their fingers.
lines.speaker: Second Servant

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: How canst thou try them so?
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Second Servant
lines.speaker: Second Servant

lines.value: Marry, sir, 'tis an ill cook that cannot lick his
lines.speaker: Second Servant

lines.value: own fingers: therefore he that cannot lick his
lines.speaker: Second Servant

lines.value: fingers goes not with me.
lines.speaker: Second Servant

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Go, be gone.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: We shall be much unfurnished for this time.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: What, is my daughter gone to Friar Laurence?
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Ay, forsooth.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Well, he may chance to do some good on her:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: A peevish self-will'd harlotry it is.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: See where she comes from shrift with merry look.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: How now, my headstrong! where have you been gadding?
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Where I have learn'd me to repent the sin
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Of disobedient opposition
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To you and your behests, and am enjoin'd
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: By holy Laurence to fall prostrate here,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And beg your pardon: pardon, I beseech you!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Henceforward I am ever ruled by you.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Send for the county; go tell him of this:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: I'll have this knot knit up to-morrow morning.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I met the youthful lord at Laurence' cell;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And gave him what becomed love I might,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Not step o'er the bounds of modesty.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Why, I am glad on't; this is well: stand up:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: This is as't should be. Let me see the county;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Ay, marry, go, I say, and fetch him hither.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Now, afore God! this reverend holy friar,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Our whole city is much bound to him.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nurse, will you go with me into my closet,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To help me sort such needful ornaments
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: As you think fit to furnish me to-morrow?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: No, not till Thursday; there is time enough.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Go, nurse, go with her: we'll to church to-morrow.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: LADY  CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY  CAPULET

lines.value: We shall be short in our provision:
lines.speaker: LADY  CAPULET

lines.value: 'Tis now near night.
lines.speaker: LADY  CAPULET

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Tush, I will stir about,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: And all things shall be well, I warrant thee, wife:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Go thou to Juliet, help to deck up her;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: I'll not to bed to-night; let me alone;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: I'll play the housewife for this once. What, ho!
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: They are all forth. Well, I will walk myself
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: To County Paris, to prepare him up
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Against to-morrow: my heart is wondrous light,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Since this same wayward girl is so reclaim'd.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Ay, those attires are best: but, gentle nurse,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I pray thee, leave me to my self to-night,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: For I have need of many orisons
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To move the heavens to smile upon my state,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Which, well thou know'st, is cross, and full of sin.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: What, are you busy, ho? need you my help?
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: No, madam; we have cull'd such necessaries
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: As are behoveful for our state to-morrow:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: So please you, let me now be left alone,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And let the nurse this night sit up with you;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: For, I am sure, you have your hands full all,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: In this so sudden business.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Good night:
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Get thee to bed, and rest; for thou hast need.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Farewell! God knows when we shall meet again.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I have a faint cold fear thrills through my veins,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: That almost freezes up the heat of life:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I'll call them back again to comfort me:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Nurse! What should she do here?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: My dismal scene I needs must act alone.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Come, vial.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What if this mixture do not work at all?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Shall I be married then to-morrow morning?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: No, no: this shall forbid it: lie thou there.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What if it be a poison, which the friar
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Subtly hath minister'd to have me dead,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Lest in this marriage he should be dishonour'd,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Because he married me before to Romeo?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I fear it is: and yet, methinks, it should not,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: For he hath still been tried a holy man.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: How if, when I am laid into the tomb,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I wake before the time that Romeo
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Come to redeem me? there's a fearful point!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Shall I not, then, be stifled in the vault,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To whose foul mouth no healthsome air breathes in,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And there die strangled ere my Romeo comes?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Or, if I live, is it not very like,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: The horrible conceit of death and night,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Together with the terror of the place,--
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: As in a vault, an ancient receptacle,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Where, for these many hundred years, the bones
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Of all my buried ancestors are packed:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Where bloody Tybalt, yet but green in earth,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Lies festering in his shroud; where, as they say,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: At some hours in the night spirits resort;--
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Alack, alack, is it not like that I,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: So early waking, what with loathsome smells,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And shrieks like mandrakes' torn out of the earth,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: That living mortals, hearing them, run mad:--
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O, if I wake, shall I not be distraught,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Environed with all these hideous fears?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And madly play with my forefather's joints?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And pluck the mangled Tybalt from his shroud?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And, in this rage, with some great kinsman's bone,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: As with a club, dash out my desperate brains?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O, look! methinks I see my cousin's ghost
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Seeking out Romeo, that did spit his body
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Upon a rapier's point: stay, Tybalt, stay!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Romeo, I come! this do I drink to thee.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Hold, take these keys, and fetch more spices, nurse.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: They call for dates and quinces in the pastry.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Come, stir, stir, stir! the second cock hath crow'd,
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: The curfew-bell hath rung, 'tis three o'clock:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Look to the baked meats, good Angelica:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Spare not for the cost.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Nurse
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Go, you cot-quean, go,
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: Get you to bed; faith, You'll be sick to-morrow
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: For this night's watching.
lines.speaker: Nurse

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: No, not a whit: what! I have watch'd ere now
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: All night for lesser cause, and ne'er been sick.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Peace, ho, for shame! confusion's cure lives not
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: In these confusions. Heaven and yourself
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Had part in this fair maid; now heaven hath all,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And all the better is it for the maid:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Your part in her you could not keep from death,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: But heaven keeps his part in eternal life.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: The most you sought was her promotion;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: For 'twas your heaven she should be advanced:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: O, in this love, you love your child so ill,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: That you run mad, seeing that she is well:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: She's not well married that lives married long;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: But she's best married that dies married young.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Dry up your tears, and stick your rosemary
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: On this fair corse; and, as the custom is,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: In all her best array bear her to church:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: For though fond nature bids us an lament,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Yet nature's tears are reason's merriment.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: My dreams presage some joyful news at hand:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: My bosom's lord sits lightly in his throne;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And all this day an unaccustom'd spirit
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Lifts me above the ground with cheerful thoughts.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I dreamt my lady came and found me dead--
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Strange dream, that gives a dead man leave
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: to think!--
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And breathed such life with kisses in my lips,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: That I revived, and was an emperor.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Ah me! how sweet is love itself possess'd,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: When but love's shadows are so rich in joy!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: How doth my lady? Is my father well?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: How fares my Juliet? that I ask again;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: For nothing can be ill, if she be well.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BALTHASAR

lines.value: Then she is well, and nothing can be ill:

lines.value: Her body sleeps in Capel's monument,
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: And her immortal part with angels lives.

lines.value: O, pardon me for bringing these ill news,

lines.value: To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I do remember an apothecary,--
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And hereabouts he dwells,--which late I noted
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: In tatter'd weeds, with overwhelming brows,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Culling of simples; meagre were his looks,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Sharp misery had worn him to the bones:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And in his needy shop a tortoise hung,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: An alligator stuff'd, and other skins
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Of ill-shaped fishes; and about his shelves
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: A beggarly account of empty boxes,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Green earthen pots, bladders and musty seeds,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Remnants of packthread and old cakes of roses,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Were thinly scatter'd, to make up a show.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Noting this penury, to myself I said
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: 'An if a man did need a poison now,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Whose sale is present death in Mantua,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Here lives a caitiff wretch would sell it him.'
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O, this same thought did but forerun my need;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And this same needy man must sell it me.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: As I remember, this should be the house.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Being holiday, the beggar's shop is shut.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: What, ho! apothecary!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Apothecary
lines.speaker: Apothecary

lines.value: Who calls so loud?
lines.speaker: Apothecary

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Come hither, man. I see that thou art poor:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Hold, there is forty ducats: let me have
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: A dram of poison, such soon-speeding gear
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: As will disperse itself through all the veins
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: That the life-weary taker may fall dead
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And that the trunk may be discharged of breath
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: As violently as hasty powder fired
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Doth hurry from the fatal cannon's womb.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Apothecary
lines.speaker: Apothecary

lines.value: Such mortal drugs I have; but Mantua's law
lines.speaker: Apothecary

lines.value: Is death to any he that utters them.
lines.speaker: Apothecary

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And fear'st to die? famine is in thy cheeks,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Contempt and beggary hangs upon thy back;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: The world is not thy friend nor the world's law;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: The world affords no law to make thee rich;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Then be not poor, but break it, and take this.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Apothecary
lines.speaker: Apothecary

lines.value: My poverty, but not my will, consents.
lines.speaker: Apothecary

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I pay thy poverty, and not thy will.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Apothecary
lines.speaker: Apothecary

lines.value: Put this in any liquid thing you will,
lines.speaker: Apothecary

lines.value: And drink it off; and, if you had the strength
lines.speaker: Apothecary

lines.value: Of twenty men, it would dispatch you straight.
lines.speaker: Apothecary

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: There is thy gold, worse poison to men's souls,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Doing more murders in this loathsome world,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Than these poor compounds that thou mayst not sell.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I sell thee poison; thou hast sold me none.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Farewell: buy food, and get thyself in flesh.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Come, cordial and not poison, go with me

lines.value: FRIAR JOHN
