lines.value: Holy Franciscan friar! brother, ho!
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: This same should be the voice of Friar John.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Welcome from Mantua: what says Romeo?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: FRIAR JOHN
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: Going to find a bare-foot brother out
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: One of our order, to associate me,
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: Here in this city visiting the sick,
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: And finding him, the searchers of the town,
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: Suspecting that we both were in a house
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: Where the infectious pestilence did reign,
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: Seal'd up the doors, and would not let us forth;
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: So that my speed to Mantua there was stay'd.
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Who bare my letter, then, to Romeo?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: FRIAR JOHN
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: I could not send it,--here it is again,--
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: Nor get a messenger to bring it thee,
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: So fearful were they of infection.
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Unhappy fortune! by my brotherhood,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: The letter was not nice but full of charge
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Of dear import, and the neglecting it
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: May do much danger. Friar John, go hence;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Get me an iron crow, and bring it straight
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Unto my cell.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: FRIAR JOHN
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: Brother, I'll go and bring it thee.
lines.speaker: FRIAR JOHN

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Now must I to the monument alone;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Within three hours will fair Juliet wake:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: She will beshrew me much that Romeo
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Hath had no notice of these accidents;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: But I will write again to Mantua,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And keep her at my cell till Romeo come;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Poor living corse, closed in a dead man's tomb!
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Give me thy torch, boy: hence, and stand aloof:
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Yet put it out, for I would not be seen.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Under yond yew-trees lay thee all along,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Holding thine ear close to the hollow ground;
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: So shall no foot upon the churchyard tread,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Being loose, unfirm, with digging up of graves,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: But thou shalt hear it: whistle then to me,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: As signal that thou hear'st something approach.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Give me those flowers. Do as I bid thee, go.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: PAGE
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: [Aside]  I am almost afraid to stand alone
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: Here in the churchyard; yet I will adventure.
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Sweet flower, with flowers thy bridal bed I strew,--
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: O woe! thy canopy is dust and stones;--
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Which with sweet water nightly I will dew,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Or, wanting that, with tears distill'd by moans:
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: The obsequies that I for thee will keep
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Nightly shall be to strew thy grave and weep.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: The boy gives warning something doth approach.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: What cursed foot wanders this way to-night,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: To cross my obsequies and true love's rite?
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: What with a torch! muffle me, night, awhile.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Give me that mattock and the wrenching iron.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Hold, take this letter; early in the morning
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: See thou deliver it to my lord and father.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Give me the light: upon thy life, I charge thee,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Whate'er thou hear'st or seest, stand all aloof,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And do not interrupt me in my course.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Why I descend into this bed of death,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Is partly to behold my lady's face;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: But chiefly to take thence from her dead finger
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: A precious ring, a ring that I must use
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: In dear employment: therefore hence, be gone:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: But if thou, jealous, dost return to pry
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: In what I further shall intend to do,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: By heaven, I will tear thee joint by joint
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And strew this hungry churchyard with thy limbs:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: The time and my intents are savage-wild,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: More fierce and more inexorable far
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Than empty tigers or the roaring sea.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BALTHASAR
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: So shalt thou show me friendship. Take thou that:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Live, and be prosperous: and farewell, good fellow.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: BALTHASAR
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: [Aside]  For all this same, I'll hide me hereabout:
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: His looks I fear, and his intents I doubt.
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Gorged with the dearest morsel of the earth,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Thus I enforce thy rotten jaws to open,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And, in despite, I'll cram thee with more food!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: This is that banish'd haughty Montague,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: That murder'd my love's cousin, with which grief,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: It is supposed, the fair creature died;
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: And here is come to do some villanous shame
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: To the dead bodies: I will apprehend him.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Stop thy unhallow'd toil, vile Montague!
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Can vengeance be pursued further than death?
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Condemned villain, I do apprehend thee:
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Obey, and go with me; for thou must die.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I must indeed; and therefore came I hither.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Fly hence, and leave me: think upon these gone;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Let them affright thee. I beseech thee, youth,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Put not another sin upon my head,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: By urging me to fury: O, be gone!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: By heaven, I love thee better than myself;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: For I come hither arm'd against myself:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Stay not, be gone; live, and hereafter say,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: A madman's mercy bade thee run away.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: I do defy thy conjurations,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: And apprehend thee for a felon here.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Wilt thou provoke me? then have at thee, boy!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: PAGE
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: O Lord, they fight! I will go call the watch.
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: PARIS
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: O, I am slain!
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: If thou be merciful,
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: Open the tomb, lay me with Juliet.
lines.speaker: PARIS

lines.value: ROMEO
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: In faith, I will. Let me peruse this face.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Mercutio's kinsman, noble County Paris!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: What said my man, when my betossed soul
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Did not attend him as we rode? I think
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: He told me Paris should have married Juliet:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Said he not so? or did I dream it so?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Or am I mad, hearing him talk of Juliet,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: To think it was so? O, give me thy hand,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: One writ with me in sour misfortune's book!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: I'll bury thee in a triumphant grave;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: A grave? O no! a lantern, slaughter'd youth,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: This vault a feasting presence full of light.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Death, lie thou there, by a dead man interr'd.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: How oft when men are at the point of death
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Have they been merry! which their keepers call
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: A lightning before death: O, how may I
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Call this a lightning? O my love! my wife!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Death, that hath suck'd the honey of thy breath,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty:
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Thou art not conquer'd; beauty's ensign yet
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And death's pale flag is not advanced there.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Tybalt, liest thou there in thy bloody sheet?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O, what more favour can I do to thee,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: To sunder his that was thine enemy?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Forgive me, cousin! Ah, dear Juliet,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Why art thou yet so fair? shall I believe
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: That unsubstantial death is amorous,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And that the lean abhorred monster keeps
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Thee here in dark to be his paramour?
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: For fear of that, I still will stay with thee;
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And never from this palace of dim night
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Depart again: here, here will I remain
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: With worms that are thy chamber-maids; O, here
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Will I set up my everlasting rest,
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: From this world-wearied flesh. Eyes, look your last!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Arms, take your last embrace! and, lips, O you
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: The doors of breath, seal with a righteous kiss
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: A dateless bargain to engrossing death!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Come, bitter conduct, come, unsavoury guide!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Thou desperate pilot, now at once run on
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: The dashing rocks thy sea-sick weary bark!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Here's to my love!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: O true apothecary!
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: Thy drugs are quick. Thus with a kiss I die.
lines.speaker: ROMEO

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Saint Francis be my speed! how oft to-night
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Have my old feet stumbled at graves! Who's there?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: BALTHASAR
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: Here's one, a friend, and one that knows you well.
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Bliss be upon you! Tell me, good my friend,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: What torch is yond, that vainly lends his light
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: To grubs and eyeless skulls? as I discern,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: It burneth in the Capel's monument.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: BALTHASAR
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: It doth so, holy sir; and there's my master,
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: One that you love.
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Who is it?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: BALTHASAR
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: Romeo.
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: How long hath he been there?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: BALTHASAR
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: Full half an hour.
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Go with me to the vault.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: BALTHASAR
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: I dare not, sir
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: My master knows not but I am gone hence;
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: And fearfully did menace me with death,
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: If I did stay to look on his intents.
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Stay, then; I'll go alone. Fear comes upon me:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: O, much I fear some ill unlucky thing.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: BALTHASAR
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: As I did sleep under this yew-tree here,
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: I dreamt my master and another fought,
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: And that my master slew him.
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Romeo!
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Alack, alack, what blood is this, which stains
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: The stony entrance of this sepulchre?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: What mean these masterless and gory swords
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: To lie discolour'd by this place of peace?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Romeo! O, pale! Who else? what, Paris too?
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And steep'd in blood? Ah, what an unkind hour
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Is guilty of this lamentable chance!
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: The lady stirs.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O comfortable friar! where is my lord?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: I do remember well where I should be,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: And there I am. Where is my Romeo?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: I hear some noise. Lady, come from that nest
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: A greater power than we can contradict
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Hath thwarted our intents. Come, come away.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And Paris too. Come, I'll dispose of thee
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Among a sisterhood of holy nuns:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Stay not to question, for the watch is coming;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Come, go, good Juliet,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: I dare no longer stay.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Go, get thee hence, for I will not away.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: What's here? a cup, closed in my true love's hand?
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end:
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: O churl! drunk all, and left no friendly drop
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To help me after? I will kiss thy lips;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Haply some poison yet doth hang on them,
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: To make die with a restorative.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Thy lips are warm.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: First Watchman
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: [Within]  Lead, boy: which way?
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: JULIET
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: Yea, noise? then I'll be brief. O happy dagger!
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: This is thy sheath;
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: there rust, and let me die.
lines.speaker: JULIET

lines.value: PAGE
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: This is the place; there, where the torch doth burn.
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: First Watchman
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: The ground is bloody; search about the churchyard:
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: Go, some of you, whoe'er you find attach.
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: Pitiful sight! here lies the county slain,
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: And Juliet bleeding, warm, and newly dead,
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: Who here hath lain these two days buried.
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: Go, tell the prince: run to the Capulets:
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: Raise up the Montagues: some others search:
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: We see the ground whereon these woes do lie;
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: But the true ground of all these piteous woes
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: We cannot without circumstance descry.
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: Second Watchman
lines.speaker: Second Watchman

lines.value: Here's Romeo's man; we found him in the churchyard.
lines.speaker: Second Watchman

lines.value: First Watchman
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: Hold him in safety, till the prince come hither.
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: Third Watchman
lines.speaker: Third Watchman

lines.value: Here is a friar, that trembles, sighs and weeps:
lines.speaker: Third Watchman

lines.value: We took this mattock and this spade from him,
lines.speaker: Third Watchman

lines.value: As he was coming from this churchyard side.
lines.speaker: Third Watchman

lines.value: First Watchman
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: A great suspicion: stay the friar too.
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: PRINCE
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: What misadventure is so early up,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: That calls our person from our morning's rest?
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: What should it be, that they so shriek abroad?
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: The people in the street cry Romeo,
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: Some Juliet, and some Paris; and all run,

lines.value: With open outcry toward our monument.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: PRINCE
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: What fear is this which startles in our ears?
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: First Watchman
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: Sovereign, here lies the County Paris slain;
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: And Romeo dead; and Juliet, dead before,
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: Warm and new kill'd.
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: PRINCE
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: First Watchman
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: Here is a friar, and slaughter'd Romeo's man;
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: With instruments upon them, fit to open
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: These dead men's tombs.
lines.speaker: First Watchman

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: O heavens! O wife, look how our daughter bleeds!
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: This dagger hath mista'en--for, lo, his house
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Is empty on the back of Montague,--

lines.value: And it mis-sheathed in my daughter's bosom!
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: LADY CAPULET
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: O me! this sight of death is as a bell,
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: That warns my old age to a sepulchre.
lines.speaker: LADY CAPULET

lines.value: PRINCE
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Come, Montague; for thou art early up,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: To see thy son and heir more early down.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Alas, my liege, my wife is dead to-night;
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: Grief of my son's exile hath stopp'd her breath:
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: What further woe conspires against mine age?
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: PRINCE
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Look, and thou shalt see.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: MONTAGUE
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: O thou untaught! what manners is in this?

lines.value: To press before thy father to a grave?

lines.value: PRINCE
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Till we can clear these ambiguities,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: And know their spring, their head, their
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: true descent;
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: And then will I be general of your woes,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: And lead you even to death: meantime forbear,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: And let mischance be slave to patience.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Bring forth the parties of suspicion.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: I am the greatest, able to do least,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Yet most suspected, as the time and place
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Doth make against me of this direful murder;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Myself condemned and myself excused.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: PRINCE
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Then say at once what thou dost know in this.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: FRIAR LAURENCE
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: I will be brief, for my short date of breath
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Is not so long as is a tedious tale.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Romeo, there dead, was husband to that Juliet;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And she, there dead, that Romeo's faithful wife:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: I married them; and their stol'n marriage-day
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Was Tybalt's dooms-day, whose untimely death
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Banish'd the new-made bridegroom from the city,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: For whom, and not for Tybalt, Juliet pined.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: You, to remove that siege of grief from her,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Betroth'd and would have married her perforce
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: To County Paris: then comes she to me,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And, with wild looks, bid me devise some mean
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: To rid her from this second marriage,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Or in my cell there would she kill herself.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Then gave I her, so tutor'd by my art,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: A sleeping potion; which so took effect
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: As I intended, for it wrought on her
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: The form of death: meantime I writ to Romeo,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: That he should hither come as this dire night,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: To help to take her from her borrow'd grave,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Being the time the potion's force should cease.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: But he which bore my letter, Friar John,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Was stay'd by accident, and yesternight
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Return'd my letter back. Then all alone
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: At the prefixed hour of her waking,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Came I to take her from her kindred's vault;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Meaning to keep her closely at my cell,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Till I conveniently could send to Romeo:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: But when I came, some minute ere the time
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Of her awaking, here untimely lay
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: The noble Paris and true Romeo dead.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: She wakes; and I entreated her come forth,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And bear this work of heaven with patience:
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: But then a noise did scare me from the tomb;
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: And she, too desperate, would not go with me,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: But, as it seems, did violence on herself.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: All this I know; and to the marriage
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Her nurse is privy: and, if aught in this
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Miscarried by my fault, let my old life
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Be sacrificed, some hour before his time,
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: Unto the rigour of severest law.
lines.speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.value: PRINCE
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: We still have known thee for a holy man.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Where's Romeo's man? what can he say in this?
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: BALTHASAR
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: I brought my master news of Juliet's death;
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: And then in post he came from Mantua
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: To this same place, to this same monument.
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: This letter he early bid me give his father,
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: And threatened me with death, going in the vault,
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: I departed not and left him there.
lines.speaker: BALTHASAR

lines.value: PRINCE
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Give me the letter; I will look on it.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Where is the county's page, that raised the watch?
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Sirrah, what made your master in this place?
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: PAGE
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: He came with flowers to strew his lady's grave;
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: And bid me stand aloof, and so I did:
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: Anon comes one with light to ope the tomb;
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: And by and by my master drew on him;
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: And then I ran away to call the watch.
lines.speaker: PAGE

lines.value: PRINCE
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: This letter doth make good the friar's words,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Their course of love, the tidings of her death:
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: And here he writes that he did buy a poison
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Of a poor 'pothecary, and therewithal
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Came to this vault to die, and lie with Juliet.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Where be these enemies? Capulet! Montague!
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: See, what a scourge is laid upon your hate,
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: That heaven finds means to kill your joys with love.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: And I for winking at your discords too
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Have lost a brace of kinsmen: all are punish'd.
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: O brother Montague, give me thy hand:
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: This is my daughter's jointure, for no more
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Can I demand.
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: MONTAGUE
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: But I can give thee more:
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: For I will raise her statue in pure gold;
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: That while Verona by that name is known,
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: There shall no figure at such rate be set
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: As that of true and faithful Juliet.
lines.speaker: MONTAGUE

lines.value: CAPULET
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: As rich shall Romeo's by his lady's lie;
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: Poor sacrifices of our enmity!
lines.speaker: CAPULET

lines.value: PRINCE
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: A glooming peace this morning with it brings;
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: The sun, for sorrow, will not show his head:
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Go hence, to have more talk of these sad things;
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Some shall be pardon'd, and some punished:
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: For never was a story of more woe
lines.speaker: PRINCE

lines.value: Than this of Juliet and her Romeo.
lines.speaker: PRINCE
